packagegui.name: bindzone
packagegui.title: BIND: Zones Settings

field.description: Do not include this zone in BIND config files.

Enter the name for this zone (e.g. example.com)
For reverse zones, include zone IP in reverse order. (e.g. 1.168.192)
Note: IN-ADDR.ARPA will be automaticaly included in config files when reverse zone option is checked.
Enter a description for this zone.
Select zone type.
Select (CTRL+click) the views that this zone will belong to.
Check if this is a reverse zone.
Check if this is an IPv6 reverse zone. Reverse Zone must also be enabled.
You can put your own custom options here.
Enable inline DNSSEC signing
Enable this option to include all DNSSEC key files in XML.

Digest fingerprint of the Key Signing Key for this zone.
Upload this DSSET to your domain root server.
If this is a slave zone, enter the IP address of the master DNS server.
Enter forwarder IPs for this domain. Separate by semicolons (;).
Default expiration time of all resource records without their own TTL value.
Enter nameserver for this zone.
Enter IP address for base domain lookup. (Meaning, what IP should nslookup mydomain.com return.)
Enter mail admin zone.
Parsed value for the slave to update the DNS zone.
Slave refresh (Default: 1 day)
Slave retry time in case of a problem (Default: 2 hours)
Slave expiration time (Default: 4 weeks)
Maximum caching time in case of failed lookups (Default: 1 hour)
Enable update-policy which overrides allow-update.
field.sethelp: The update-policy statement replaces the allow-update statement.

field.description:
The update-policy statement defines the policy for submitting dynamic updates to 'master' zones.
Note: Do NOT include the surrounding { } when using multiple statements!

Select (CTRL+click) who is allowed to query this zone.
The allow-query statement defines a match list of IP address(es) which are allowed to issue queries to the server.

"Record" is the name or last octet of an IP. (Example: www, pop, smtp)
"Type" is the type of the record. (Example: A, CNAME, MX, NS)
"Priority" is used only in MX records to define their priority.
"Alias or IP address" is the destination host or IP address.

Note: You can order the elements on this list with drag and drop.

rowhelperfield.description: Select record type for this host.
Enter the IP address or FQDN destination for domain's MX (Example: 10.31.11.1 or mail.example.com)

field.description: If this option is set, then DHCP static mappings will be registered in DNS, so that their name can be resolved.

Paste any custom zone records to include in this zone.
This can be used for a fast migration setup.
Resulting BIND config file for this zone.
